guideline.rule: Assume the agent already understands common concepts; only include context that changes decisions or prevents mistakes.
guideline.rationale: Reduces token load after a skill is selected and keeps instructions focused on what is unique to the workflow or project.

guideline.rule: Write the frontmatter description in third person, and include both what the skill does and when to use it.
guideline.rationale: The description is injected into the system prompt and is used for skill selection; point-of-view drift reduces match quality.

guideline.rule: Keep SKILL.md as an entrypoint: a concise overview + clear navigation to any linked reference files.
guideline.rationale: Roo Code does not automatically load linked files; SKILL.md must make it obvious which file to read next (and why).

guideline.rule: Choose an appropriate degree of freedom: use strict, step-by-step instructions for fragile workflows; use heuristics when multiple approaches are valid.
guideline.rationale: Overly rigid skills break in novel contexts; overly loose skills skip validation in high-stakes workflows.

guideline.rule: Write descriptions for retrieval: include concrete keywords, tools, file types, and user phrasing triggers.
guideline.rationale: Improves selection accuracy during skill matching.

guideline.rule: Make the description actionable: describe what the skill DOES and when to use it.
guideline.rationale: Vague descriptions reduce match quality and increase false positives/negatives.

guideline.rule: Start SKILL.md with "When to use" and "When NOT to use".
guideline.rationale: Prevents accidental activation and reduces false positives.

guideline.rule: Prefer short, numbered steps with explicit inputs/outputs.
guideline.rationale: Agents follow procedural instructions more reliably than prose.

guideline.rule: Use progressive disclosure: keep SKILL.md concise; move deep reference into references/.
guideline.rationale: Minimizes context usage while preserving detail on demand.

guideline.rule: Prefer a single recommended default approach with an explicit escape hatch (only add multiple alternatives when necessary).
guideline.rationale: Too many options reduces reliability and increases variance in execution.

guideline.rule: When referencing files, use forward slashes in paths (even on Windows) and keep references one level deep from SKILL.md.
guideline.rationale: Forward slashes are cross-platform, and shallow references reduce accidental partial/irrelevant reads.

guideline.rule: For longer reference files, include a short table of contents near the top to make selective reading easier.
guideline.rationale: Helps the agent jump to the correct section without reading the entire file.

guideline.rule: Heuristic size rule: keep SKILL.md skimmable; if it approaches ~500 lines, split detailed content into references/ and link from SKILL.md.
guideline.rationale: Roo Code does not enforce a SKILL.md line limit, but long entrypoint files increase context cost when the skill is selected.

example_refinement.user_phrase: I want a skill for making API docs
example_refinement.refined_description: Generate OpenAPI documentation from TypeScript/JavaScript source using JSDoc comments

guideline.rule: Keep skill names stable; treat renames as breaking changes.
Prefer one-level file references from SKILL.md (e.g., references/REFERENCE.md, scripts/run.sh).
Make intent explicit for scripts: state whether the agent should execute the script or read it as reference.
guideline.rationale: Most scripts should be executed for deterministic behavior; reading is only needed when understanding the logic matters.

guideline.rule: Use the optional compatibility field only when it meaningfully constrains runtime requirements.
